node.text: Rachel Gurjar (@rachelgurjar) is showing us her take on a classic gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from her Indian heritage. With curry leaves, mango, and lime juice, this tangy and super refreshing cocktail feels like summer in a glass. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Curry Leaf and Mango G&T

node.text: Al Thompson (@drunkenmixologist) shares his version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. With the combination of bright, citrusy grapefruit and floral lavender, this G&T becomes the perfect rooftop cocktail. Simple. Refreshing. Delicious. #StirCreativity

node.text: Watch as @eatwithchrissy makes a tangy, slightly spicy margarita using @cointreau_us, Scotch bonnet peppers, grapefruit, lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita uses Scotch Bonnet peppers to give a satisfying kick.

node.title: Margarita Season: Scotch Bonnet and Grapefruit Margarita

node.text: Watch as @andybaraghani makes a sweet and refreshing margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled pineapple and mint, and lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita is quite possibly *the* drink of summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Crushed Pineapple and Mint Margarita

node.text: Melissa Miranda (@meltronica) shares her version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from the Philippines with a riff on the Gin Pom. With grapefruit, ginger, cardamom bitters, a squeeze of lime, and @bombaysapphireus, this drink will remind you of being on the beach. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Ginger Grapefruit G&T

node.text: Julie Reiner (@mixtressnyc) is showing us how to make her spin on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. Julie grew up in Hawai'i and uses that for her inspiration, with watermelon, lemon, and coconut water for a bright burst of summer. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Watermelon Coconut G&T

node.text:
**Sound On** In honor of Mother’s Day, best-selling author and poet Kwame Alexander (@kwamealexander) asked 12 accomplished writers to reflect on how their lives—and their kitchens—mirror their mothers. Everyone got the same prompt, “I am becoming my mother,” and this community poem is a result. Head to the link in our bio to read more about the authors.
Contributors: @vanggarrett, Lesléa Newman, @engle.margarita, @marjorythw, Richard Michelson, Janet Wong, @georgiaheard1, @amstephens_, Maritza Rivera, Reuben Jackson, Lorna Goodison, @erikalsanchez, Deanna Nikaido, and Kwame Alexander

node.title: Kwame Alexander Reads The Ceremony of Giving

node.text: Watch as @empschultz makes a salty blueberry and ginger Margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled blueberry, ginger simple syrup, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita was inspired by a blueberry, ginger, and orange pie she made last summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Salty Blueberry & Ginger Margarita

node.text: DeVonn Francis (@tuna__turner) is showing us how to make his unique take on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. DeVonn uses pineapple as a nod to his Caribbean roots, celery to compliment the herbaceous notes in the gin, and bay leaf to tie all the ingredients in his Pineapple Celery G&T.

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Pineapple Celery G&T

node.text: #Ad Esther Choi (@choibites), chef/owner of @mokbar_nyc, is showing us how to make a mandu stir-fry with lots of vegetables and of course, @bibigoUSA’s mandu.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 06, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: Chef-author-activist Bryant Terry’s (@bryantterry) luscious jackfruit tamales are not only a fascinating look at the crossover between Mexican and African American foodways, but proof that truly great tamales don’t require meat. Terry created this recipe in honor of the tamales he grew up eating, sold by an independent Black food vendor known as the “Tamale Man” who parked outside a Memphis skating rink. In a nod to the Southern African American tradition of tamale-making, he uses grits (a hot tamale staple) in the dough instead of masa. And to make them vegan, Terry fills the tamales with jackfruit, a tropical fruit that mimics the texture of meat. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: Oriana Koren 🍴: @mrsmochi 🥣: @jjoules

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 06, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

node.text: This silky, luxurious corn and clam chowder from senior food editor Andy Baraghani (@andybaraghani) is a slurpable ode to summer’s golden child. The puréed corn lends body to the briny-yet-bright broth, giving this soup its smooth texture. And did we mention that this dish is completely dairy-free? Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @blackliger_ 🍴: @miamifoodstylist 🥣: @elle_jaime

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 05, 2021. May be an image of dessert.

node.text: This cinnamon-roll-inspired cake by Jocelyn Delk Adams of @grandbabycakes is a fun twist on a classic pound cake. Featured in @bryantterry’s book ‘Black Food’ and inspired by her grandmother, whose buttery cakes were famous in her hometown of Winona, Mississippi, the batter gets swirled with a brown sugar–cinnamon spice mixture. “Drizzled with cream cheese icing, it will remind you of those pillowy soft and fluffy cinnamon rolls you may have indulged in for breakfast,” Adams says. Click the link in our bio to treat yourself—you deserve it! 📷: Oriana Koren 🍴: @mrsmochi 🥣: @jjoules

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 05, 2021. May be an image of tomato.

node.text: In the dog days of summer, we’re beyond grateful for this no-cook gazpacho recipe, which comes together quickly in a blender. But since it's completely uncooked, you've got to make sure that you're using the absolute best tomatoes possible. For this recipe by Rick Martinez (@rick_andrew_martinez), you’ll want at least two varieties: heirlooms for the base and cherry tomatoes for the garnish. Click the link in our bio to make this refreshing dish. 📷: @yungbludlau

node.text: Associate food editor Jessie YuChen (@thelescook) is bringing the heat and the sweetness with these grilled hot honey wings. Watch the full video on YouTube at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, dessert and indoor.

node.text: These light and fluffy yeasted doughnuts are coated with rich maple glaze for an effect reminiscent of a pancake breakfast. The key to making these doughnuts by developer Samantha Seneviratne (@samantaseneviratne) is making sure you use a pot that can hold a couple inches of oil and still have another inch or two of empty space above it. (Yes, deep frying is necessary. But it’s not as hard as it sounds!) Click the link in our bio to make these super glossy and super delicious treats. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rice.isnice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 03, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: When chef Rawlston Williams (@chefrawlstonw) was growing up in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, his curry vegetables were cooked in coconut milk made from scratch. These days, Williams relies on the canned stuff to make a version of a Caribbean-style curry with zucchini, carrots, cauliflower, eggplant, okra, and mushrooms. You can feel free to use whatever produce you want in this recipe—the intense combination of curry powder, turmeric, and rich coconut milk will make any mix of veggies taste delicious. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 02, 2021. May be an image of shrimp and indoor.

node.text: Many Filipinx families have their own take on kare-kare, a stew made with a base sauce that includes peanut butter, achiote (annatto) seed, and often a fermented shrimp paste called bagoong for extra flavor. In this recipe, chef Harold Villarosa (@chefharoldvillarosa) reimagines the stew as a rich sauce for seared shrimp by cooking down bottled @eatfilamanila Kare-Kare with garlic, thyme, chicken broth, butter, lemon juice, and hot sauce. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

May be an image of text that says 'bon appétit FOOD PEOPLE "I realized that the more of a food person I became, the closer I got to my identity and my culture, and I want to keep going." RACHEL GURJAR Bon Appétit Associate Food Editor'.

node.text: Tell us you’re a food person without *telling* us you’re a food person. On this week’s episode of Food People, we talk about drinking milkshakes for breakfast, making kimchi with our grandmothers, and counting cheeseburgers when we can’t sleep. Plus Rachel Gurjar (@rachelgurjar) and Devonn Francis (@tuna__turner) talk about how they found their own food paths. Head to the link in our bio to hear their stories, and to find out who that a.m. milkshake maker is.

Photo by bonappetitmag on September 02, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: Crisp-tender cucumbers and deeply browned pork crumbles add delightful texture to this quick and savory weeknight stir-fry from senior food editor Christina Chaey (@seechaey). And while this dish comes together in no time, it gets big flavor from a judicious dollop of oyster sauce, which lends a punch of of umami-rich, sweet-meets-saltiness to the table. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

node.text: Seen a lot of celebrity wines lately? Us too. Luckily @andrehmack is here to tell us about the quality, taste, and value of 16 of them. Watch the full video on YouTube at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 01, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text: Up until her parents got divorced, when contributor Chloé Caldwell (@chloeeeecaldwell) was 14, her family sat around their cherrywood table eating the types of dinners that were hallmarks of middle-class white families living in upstate New York in the '90s: meatloaf, Minute Rice, and stew. Then her dad moved out, her brother left for boarding school, and dinners were never the same again. “Instead of fussing over roast chickens and long-form lasagne, we became our own lean, mean unit of two—eating grilled chicken over greens and toasted English muffins stuffed with salami and molten cheese,” she writes. As Caldwell watched her mom embrace her newfound independence, she vowed, in the name of feminism, never to marry or become a woman who cooked. That is, until she fell in love and had a family of her own to feed. Click the link in our bio to read Caldwell’s essay. 🎨: @tallulahfontaine
